case_name: Income-tax Officer, Madura v. M.R. Vidyasagar

facts.text: Civil Appeal Nos. 545 and 546 of 1960 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal Nos. 545 and 546 of 1960. Appeals from the judgment and order dated August 13, 1954, of the Madras High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 743 and 748 of 1954.

facts.text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated August 13, 1954, of the Madras High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 743 and 748 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated August 13, 1954, of the Madras High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 743 and 748 of 1954. N. Rajagopal Sastri and P. D. Menon, for the appellants. The respondent did number appear.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on January 17, 1962 by SHAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. January 17.-The Judgment of the companyrt was delivered by SHAH, J.-These are two appeals with certificates of fitness granted by the High Court of Judicature at Madras against certain orders passed in Writ Petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Ramaswami Iyer, father of the respondent, was assessed to income-tax in the status of a Hindu Undivided Family.

anchor.surface_text: One Ramaswami Iyer-father of the respondent- was assessed to income-tax in the status of a Hindu Undivided Family. Ramaswami Iyer died in 1949 and the respondent M.R. Vidyasagar became the manager of the family.

facts.text: Ramaswami Iyer died in 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Ramaswami Iyer died in 1949 and the respondent M.R. Vidyasagar became the manager of the family. The family was a partner through its manager in a firm styled The Madura Knitting Company, and the share in the profits of the partnership which was registered under the Indian Income-tax Act was the principal source of its assessable income.

facts.text: Respondent M.R. Vidyasagar became the manager of the family after Ramaswami Iyer's death.

anchor.surface_text: and the respondent M.R. Vidyasagar became the manager of the family. The family was a partner through its manager in a firm styled The Madura Knitting Company, and the share in the profits of the partnership which was registered under the Indian Income-tax Act was the principal source of its assessable income.

facts.text: The family was a partner through its manager in a firm styled The Madura Knitting Company.

anchor.surface_text: The family was a partner through its manager in a firm styled The Madura Knitting Company, and the share in the profits of the partnership which was registered under the Indian Income-tax Act was the principal source of its assessable income. Under s. 18A of the Indian Income-tax Act, the Hindu undivided family was liable to pay advance tax for each of the assessment years 1946-47, 1947-48 and 1948-49.

facts.text: Share in profits of Madura Knitting Company was the principal source of assessable income of the family.

anchor.surface_text: and the share in the profits of the partnership which was registered under the Indian Income-tax Act was the principal source of its assessable income. Under s. 18A of the Indian Income-tax Act, the Hindu undivided family was liable to pay advance tax for each of the assessment years 1946-47, 1947-48 and 1948-49.

facts.text: HUF liable to pay advance tax for assessment years 1946-47, 1947-48, 1948-49 under s.18A.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 18A of the Indian Income-tax Act, the Hindu undivided family was liable to pay advance tax for each of the assessment years 1946-47, 1947-48 and 1948-49. The Income-tax Officer, Madura, issued numberices under s. 18A  1  of the Indian Income-tax Act for payment of advance tax on the basis of the preceding years income.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer, Madura, issued notices under s.18A(1) for advance tax based on preceding year's income.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, Madura, issued numberices under s. 18A  1  of the Indian Income-tax Act for payment of advance tax on the basis of the preceding years income. It was open to the assessee to submit a revised estimate of his income under s. 18A  2  in respect of the year in question and Ramaswami Iyer-who was at the material time the manager-availed himself of the option to submit a revised estimate and estimated the income for each of the assessment years 1946-47 and 1948-49 at Rs. 45,000/-

facts.text: Ramaswami Iyer submitted revised estimate of income at Rs.45,000/- for 1946-47 and 1948-49 under s.18A(2).

anchor.surface_text: It was open to the assessee to submit a revised estimate of his income under s. 18A  2  in respect of the year in question and Ramaswami Iyer-who was at the material time the manager-availed himself of the option to submit a revised estimate and estimated the income for each of the assessment years 1946-47 and 1948-49 at Rs. 45,000/-

facts.text: Assessments completed on November 28, 1950 for 1946-47 and February 29, 1951 for 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: . The assessments of these two years were companypleted respectively on November 28, 1950 and February 29, 1951, and the income received from the Madura Knitting Company was included in the assessments under s. 23 5 . The Income Tax Officer assessed the total income of the Hindu undivided family for the year 1946-47 at Rs. 1,01,335/- and for the year 1948-49 at Rs. 3,10,697/-

facts.text: Total income assessed at Rs.1,01,335/- for 1946-47 and Rs.3,10,697/- for 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: The Income Tax Officer assessed the total income of the Hindu undivided family for the year 1946-47 at Rs. 1,01,335/- and for the year 1948-49 at Rs. 3,10,697/-. As the total income assessed far exceeded the estimate of Rs. 45,000/-, submitted by the manager of the assessee family, the Income Tax Officer in making the assessment ordered the respondent to pay Rs. 6,999/12/- and Rs. 36,687/- respectively for the assessment years 1946-47 and 1948-49 as interest.

facts.text: ITO ordered interest of Rs.6,999/12/- for 1946-47 and Rs.36,687/- for 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: As the total income assessed far exceeded the estimate of Rs. 45,000/-, submitted by the manager of the assessee family, the Income Tax Officer in making the assessment ordered the respondent to pay Rs. 6,999/12/- and Rs. 36,687/- respectively for the assessment years 1946-47 and 1948-49 as interest.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal by order dated March 12, 1954 reduced income of Madura Knitting Company and family's share to Rs.83,335/- for 1946-47 and Rs.2,83,868/- for 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: In appeals against the orders of assessment by the Madura Knitting Company, by order dated March 12, 1954 the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal reduced the income of the firm, and on that basis reduced the share of the family in the income of the firm for the year 1946-47 to Rs. 83,335/- and for the year 1948-49 to Rs. 2,83,868/-.

facts.text: ITO reduced interest to Rs.4,358/- for 1946-47 and Rs.32,714/10/- for 1948-49 pursuant to Tribunal order under 3rd proviso to s.18A(6).

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, Madura, in giving effect to the orders passed by the Appellate Tribunal under the 3rd proviso to s. 18A  6  reduced the interest to Rs. 4,358/- for the year 1946-47 and to Rs. 32,714/10/- for the year 1948-49, and called upon the respondent to pay the arrears of tax inclusive of interest so adjusted.

facts.text: Respondent requested ITO not to levy interest under s.18A(6) or waive it under 5th proviso added by Act 25 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then called upon the Income Tax Officer number to levy interest under s. 18A  6  submitting that the levy was illegal and unjustified, and in the alternative requested that the interest be waived under the powers vested under the 5th proviso to s. 18A  6  which was added by s. 13 of the Indian Income-tax  Amendment  Act  25 of 1953 .

facts.text: ITO declined request to waive interest; Inspecting Assistant Commissioner rejected application to cancel levy.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer declined to accede to the request and the respondents application to the Inspecting Assistant Commissioner for cancelling the levy of interest was also rejected.

facts.text: Respondent filed Writ Petitions Nos. 743 and 748 under Art. 226 in Madras High Court for writs cancelling interest orders.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then moved two petitions  Nos. 743 and 748  under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Judicature at Madras for writs cancelling the orders imposing liability for payment of interest, companytending that the levy of penal interest was opposed to law and was prima facie, unjustified on the facts and circumstances of the case.

facts.text: Madras High Court by Division Bench held levy under s.18A(6) not opposed to law, but directed ITO to consider waiver under 5th proviso.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the Madras High Court held that the provision imposing liability to pay interest under sub-s.  6  of s. 18A was number opposed to law and companyld be enforced against the legal representative of the deceased manager, who was a partner of the assessee firm.

facts.text: Appeals preferred by Commissioner of Income Tax with certificates of fitness.

anchor.surface_text: Against that order with certificates of fitness these appeals are preferred by the Commissioner of Income Tax.

facts.text: Section 18A incorporated by Act 11 of 1944.

anchor.surface_text: Section 18A which imposes liability upon the tax payer to make advance payment of tax was incorporated into the Indian Income-tax Act by Act 11 of 1944.

facts.text: 5th proviso to s.18A(6) added by s.13 of Act 25 of 1953 with retrospective effect from April 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: But by s. 13 of the Indian Income-tax  Amendment  Act, 1953  25 of 1953 , an additional proviso was enacted to sub-s.  6  in the following form Provided further that in such cases and under such circumstances as may be prescribed, the Income-tax Officer may reduce or waive the interest payable by the assessee. This proviso was given retrospective effect as from April 1, 1952.

facts.text: Rule 48 added by Central Board of Revenue under s.59 specifying circumstances for reduction/waiver of interest.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Appellate Tribunal was passed on April 12, 1953, i.e. after the date on which Act 25 of 1953 came into operation.

Thereafter in exercise of powers conferred by s. 59 the Central Board of Revenue added Rule 48 to the following effect- The Income-tax Officer may reduce or waive the interest payable under section 18A in the cases and under the circumstances mentioned below, namely- Where the relevant assessment is completed more than one year after the submission of the return, the delay in assessment not being attributable to the assessee. Where a person is under section 43 deemed to be an agent of another person and is assessed upon the latters income. Where the assessee has income from an unregistered firm to which the provisions of clause  b  of sub-section  5  of section 23 are applied. Where the previous year is the financial year or any year ending near about the close of the financial year and large profits are made after the 15th of March in circumstances which could not be foreseen. Any case in which the Inspecting Assistant Commissioner considers that the circumstances are such that a reduction or waiver of the interest payable under section 18A  6  is justified.

concepts.interpretation: Prescribes circumstances for ITO to reduce/waive interest under s.18A(6); power exercisable even after assessment if delay not attributable to assessee etc.; supports post-assessment application.

anchor.surface_text: Section 18A which imposes liability upon the tax payer to make advance payment of tax was incorporated into the Indian Income-tax Act by Act 11 of 1944.

But by s. 13 of the Indian Income-tax  Amendment  Act, 1953  25 of 1953 , an additional proviso was enacted to sub-s.  6  in the following form Provided further that in such cases and under such circumstances as may be prescribed, the Income-tax Officer may reduce or waive the interest payable by the assessee.

concepts.interpretation: Added 5th proviso to s.18A(6) with retrospective effect from 1.4.1952.

issues.text: whether the benefit of the fifth proviso to s. 18A(6) could be claimed in respect of the assessments of the income of the respondents family which were completed by the Income-tax Officer before April 1, 1952

anchor.surface_text: The only question which falls to be determined in these appeals is whether the benefit of the fifth proviso to s. 18A 6 could be claimed in respect of the assessments of the income of the respondents family which were completed by the Income-tax Officer before April 1, 1952.

issues.text: whether in an assessment subject to an appeal which is pending, or which may be lawfully filed, the power to reduce or waive the interest can be exercised

anchor.surface_text: The question which falls to be determined is whether in an assessment subject to an appeal which is pending, or which may be lawfully filed, the power to reduce or waive the interest can be exercised.

issues.text: whether the levy of interest under s. 18A(6) was penal in character and could not be imposed upon the legal representative of the deceased manager

anchor.surface_text: The respondent submitted that the levy of interest under s. 18A 6 was penal in character and could not be imposed upon the legal representative of the deceased manager who was not in any manner responsible for the original return filed by the firm of which the manager was a partner.

issues.text: whether the Income-tax Officer and Inspecting Assistant Commissioner failed to consider whether reduction or waiver of interest was justified under the 5th proviso to s. 18A(6)

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the Madras High Court held that the provision imposing liability to pay interest under sub-s. 6 of s. 18A was not opposed to law and could be enforced against the legal representative of the deceased manager, who was a partner of the assessee firm. The High Court, however, was of the view that as the Income-tax Officer and the Inspecting Assistant Commissioner had failed to consider whether in the circumstances of the case, the reduction or waiver of the interest was justified

issues.text: whether liability to pay interest under s. 18A(6) crystallizes upon completion of regular assessment and cannot be reduced or waived thereafter

anchor.surface_text: It was urged that the interest under s. 18A 6 is payable upto the date of the regular assessment and if in the contingencies prescribed by s. 18A 6 , as originally enacted liability to pay interest crystallized, the Income-tax Officer could not, in exercise of the power invested by the amending Act reopen the order

arguments.claim: Benefit of fifth proviso to s.18A(6) cannot be claimed for assessments completed before April 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The only question which falls to be determined in these appeals is whether the benefit of the fifth proviso to s. 18A 6 could be claimed in respect of the assessments of the income of the respondents family which were completed by the Income-tax Officer before April 1, 1952.

arguments.court_reasoning: Power exercisable if appeal pending even if assessment pre-1952.

arguments.claim: Liability to pay interest under s.18A(6) crystallizes upon completion of regular assessment and cannot be reopened even if appeal pending.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged that the interest under s. 18A 6 is payable upto the date of the regular assessment and if in the contingencies prescribed by s. 18A 6 , as originally enacted liability to pay interest crystallized, the Income-tax Officer could not, in exercise of the power invested by the amending Act reopen the order,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: was to be exercised only in respect of assessments made by the Income-tax Officer after that date. In our judgment, the jurisdiction under the fifth p

arguments.court_reasoning: Order modifiable on appeal, no crystallization; Rule 48 allows post-assessment.

arguments.claim: Amending Act has only partial retroactive operation, cannot enlarge to allow reopening of crystallized assessments.

anchor.surface_text: because the legislature had given to the amending statute only a partial retroactive operation and its retroactivity could not be enlarged to do so, would be plainly to defeat the plain intendment of the Legislature.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: to adjust liability to pay interest under cl.  6  of s. 18A we see numberreason why in adjusting that liability he may number exercise the powers with

arguments.court_reasoning: Legislature evinced intention for assessments post-1952 but Rule 48 supports broader.

arguments.claim: Rule 48 indicates power to reduce/waive interest exercisable even after regular assessment completed before April 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The question which falls to be determined is whether in an assessment subject to an appeal which is pending, or which may be lawfully filed, the power to reduce or waive the interest can be exercised. There is, in our judgment, inherent evidence in the rule indicating that such a power can be exercised even if the regular assessment is completed

arguments.claim: Clauses 1 and 5 of Rule 48 support order reducing/waiving interest post-assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The terms of clauses  1  and  5  of the Rule clearly support the view that the order reducing or waiving interest may be passed even after the order of assessment is made, and interest is included.

arguments.claim: Retrospective operation from April 1, 1952 shows legislative intent to apply to regular assessments made after that date.

anchor.surface_text: Again, by making Act 25 of 1953 operative retrospectively from April 1, 1952, the Legislature has evinced an intention that to regular assessments made between April 1, 1952, and the date on which the Act was enacted, the fifth proviso to 18A 6  may apply.

arguments.claim: Argument of crystallization of liability has no force as interest order modifiable on appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The argument that liability to pay interest crystallizes when the Income-tax Officer incorporates the direction for payment of interest, because the order is not made appealable has no force. The order for payment of interest was liable to be modified if the assessment of income was varied by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, or by the Tribunal.

arguments.claim: Jurisdiction under fifth proviso exercisable in cases pending on April 1, 1952 before ITO or superior authority, or commenced after.
In this case, since Tribunal order post-1952, ITO bound to adjust and exercise waiver power if warranted.

holdings.text: The benefit of the fifth proviso to s. 18A(6) can be claimed in respect of assessments completed before April 1, 1952 if the case is pending before the Income-tax Officer or any superior authority on that date.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Retrospective effect from April 1, 1952 applies to pending cases; Rule 48 contemplates post-assessment exercise; no bar to pre-1952 assessments if modifiable on appeal.

holdings.text: In an assessment subject to a pending appeal or one that may be lawfully filed, the power to reduce or waive interest under the fifth proviso to s. 18A(6) can be exercised even if regular assessment completed before April 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The question which falls to be determined is whether in an assessment subject to an appeal which is pending, or which may be lawfully filed, the power to reduce or waive the interest can be exercised. There is, in our judgment, inherent evidence in the rule indicating that such a power can be exercised even if the regular assessment is completed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inherent in Rule 48; clauses 1 and 5 allow post-assessment orders; retrospective operation supports.

holdings.text: The High Court was right in issuing a writ under Art. 226 directing the Income-tax Officer to consider whether to exercise discretion under the fifth proviso to s. 18A(6) as ITO failed to do so.
holdings.reasoning_summary: ITO bound to adjust interest post-Tribunal order and exercise waiver power if circumstances warrant; failure justifies mandamus.

holdings.text: Liability to pay interest under s. 18A(6) does not crystallize upon completion of regular assessment and remains modifiable upon appellate variation of income.

anchor.surface_text: The argument that liability to pay interest crystallizes when the Income-tax Officer incorporates the direction for payment of interest, because the order is not made appealable has no force. The order for payment of interest was liable to be modified if the assessment of income was varied by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, or by the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interest order modifiable under 3rd proviso on appeal; no independent appealability does not cause crystallization.

holdings.text: Rule 48 authorizes the Income-tax Officer to reduce or waive interest under s. 18A(6) even after the assessment order is made and interest included therein.

anchor.surface_text: The terms of clauses 1 and 5 of the Rule clearly support the view that the order reducing or waiving interest may be passed even after the order of assessment is made, and interest is included.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clauses 1 (delay in assessment) and 5 (IAC discretion) contemplate exercise post-assessment.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the High Court was right in holding that the Income-tax officer had the power in the case of the assessments in question to exercise the authority companyferred by the fifth proviso to s. 18A 6

outcome.relief_summary: High Court order upheld; writ directing the Income-tax Officer to consider exercise of discretion to reduce or waive interest under fifth proviso to s. 18A(6) is proper
directions: Income-tax Officer to consider whether a case is made out for the exercise of his discretion

anchor.surface_text: The question which falls to be determined is whether in an assessment subject to an appeal which is pending, or which may be lawfully filed, the power to reduce or waive the interest can be exercised. There is, in our judgment, inherent evidence in the rule indicating that such a power can be exercised even if the regular assessment is completed

anchor.surface_text: The argument that liability to pay interest crystallizes when the Income-tax Officer incorporates the direction for payment of interest, because the order is not made appealable has no force. The order for payment of interest was liable to be modified if the assessment of income was varied by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, or by the Tribunal.
